oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "That's My Weakness Now"
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Couples; Streams; Trees; African Americans; Landscape photographs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page featuring at center a landscape drawing with trees, a creek, and the sun. A tiny photograph of an African-American couple has been pasted onto the landscape amidst the trees. The remainder of the page includes the text, "That's my weakness now," "I must be dreaming," "Girl of my dreams," and "Get out and - get under the moon."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: College presidents; Universities & colleges; Educational facilities; Families; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page contains images of Fisk University President Thomas E. Jones, Jubilee Hall, and President Jones with his wife and child.
Image 1. Thomas E. Jones; Image 2: Jubilee Hall; Image 3. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Jones

Jubilee Hall, a National historic landmark, was the first permanent structure in the South built for the education of African-American students. Thomas E. Jones was the fifth president of Fisk University from 1926 to 1946, and the last white president.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Young female students shown in various poses: lying on the school lawn, standing posed with one foot on the school lawn, standing in front of an automobile, sitting on an automobile, and climbing a tree on campus.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Flowers; Carnations; Women; Men; Couples; Students; Courtship; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page featuring William Henry Fort Jr. and his girlfriend Marguerite. Includes cropped photos of Fort and Marguerite at left and right, with captions ""The Sunday After Initiation"" and ""Ain't She Sweet."" Center image shows a photo of the couple surrounded by a bouquet of red and white carnations in a blue vase; the white carnations have written on them in red ink various important dates and events for the couple. Text notes that the couple broke up on August 31, 1928.
Images 1-2. William Henry Fort, Jr. and Marguerite _____; Image 3. Marguerite _____

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Universities & colleges; Educational facilities; Libraries; Lecture halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page containing three images of Fisk University buildings. L-r: Chase Hall, the Library, and Livingston Hall.

Chase Hall (Science Building) was built in 1906, on the site where the statue of W.E.B. DuBois now stands. In 1908, the Carnegie Library was erected and currently serves as the Academic Building. Livingston Hall was built in 1882.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Universities & colleges; Bell towers; Chapels; Houses; Lecture halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page contains images of Bennett Hall, the Bell Tower, Memorial Chapel, and the Dunn House.
Bennett Hall, named after the Reverend H.S. Bennett, was built in 1891. Fisk Memorial Chapel was built in 1892, by funds from the estate of Clinton B. Fisk.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Women; Students; Universities & colleges; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page contains images of Langston Hughes among other individuals on Fisk's campus.
Image 1. Mrs. Colleen Jones; Image 2. Miss Raiford; Image 3. L-r: C. Lodner, Langston Hughes, and T.T.F. Fletcher; Image 4. Langston Hughes

Langston Hughes (1902-1967) was a poet, playwright, essayist, and lecturer. Often called the ""poet laureate of the Harlem Renaissance,"" Hughes was a contemporary of Charles S. Johnson. At the time this photograph was taken, Johnson was a Fisk faculty

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Women; Students; Universities & colleges; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page contains images of individual students on Fisk's campus. The students are from the classes of 1928-1930. A few photographs show Jubilee Hall in the background.
Image 1. Johnetta; Image 2. Caroline; Image 3. Ellen; Image 4. Scoville; Image 5. Ella; Image 6. ""Tony"" [surnames not given]
Constructed with proceeds from the 1871 Jubilee Singers' tour and dedicated in 1876, Fisk's Jubilee Hall was the first permanent structure erected in the South for the education of African Americans

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Floods; Universities & colleges; Games; Houses; Men; Young adults
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page contains three photographs. Upper two show flooded houses in Nashville, 1926. Bottom shows five young men building a human pyramid while others exercise around horizontal bars.
The great Cumberland River flood of 1926 displaced 7,000-10,000 people. It inspired Bessie Smith’s hit song, “Back-Water Blues."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page containing images of couples from Fisk University, classes of 1927-1929. Four young African-American couples are pictured.
Image 1. L-r: Phoebe and Clarence, Thel and Alcee, Marg and Ben, and Gene and Anna Lou [surnames not given]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: By The Leaves Ye Shall Know Them
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Lawyers; African Americans; Darrow, Clarence, 1857-1938; Neal, John Randolph, 1874-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scrapbook page. Center photograph pictures two men, Clarence Darrow and Judge John R. Neal. Underneath are three smaller photographs of African-American women, each cut in the shape of a cloverleaf. At left is Lois, at center is Dot, and at right is Marguerite. Above Dot's picture are the words "sweet thing." The bottom of the page reads, "By The Leaves Ye Shall Know Them."
Image 1. Clarence Darrow; Image 2. Judge John R. Neal; Image 3. Lois _____; Image 4. Dot _____; Image 5. Marguerite _____
Clarence Darrow was an attorney and civil libertarian most famous for defending Leopold and and Loeb in 1924 and John T. Scopes in 1925. John R. Neal was another defense lawyer for Scopes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fathers; Boys; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three pictures are shown on this scrapbook page. The first shows an African-American man and is labeled ""My own dad."" The second is of an African-American boy and reads "me - summer '26." The third, also a young African-American boy, is labeled, "The Same '23." These are presumed to be William Henry Fort, Jr. and his father, William Henry Fort, Sr.
Image 1. William Henry Fort, Sr.; Images 2-3. William Henry Fort, Jr.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Students; Universities & colleges; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite photograph of sixty-six graduates of the Fisk University Class of 1928. Head and shoulder photos are set in ovals. Class officers are listed first, then men, then women. Class officers include William H. Fort, Jr., Preston A. Merry, Charles L. Johnson

Image 1. William H. Fort, Sgt. At Arms; (Ms.) Preston A. Merry, Ass't Sec'y; Clarence L. Austion, VP; James A. McLendon, Pres.; William Moore, Treas.; Madie D. Sessoms, Sec'y; and Charles W. Morgan, Bus. Mgr. and other graduates, all named.
